title: U.S. Says Iran Likely Behind Ship Attacks
summary: Officials say two Saudi oil tankers and vessels from Norway and the U..A.E. were damaged. An initial U.S. assessment indicated Iran likely was behind the attack on two Saudi Arabian oil tankers and two other vessels damaged over the weekend near the Strait of Hormuz, a U.S. official said, a finding that, if confirmed, would further inflame military tensions in the Persian Gulf.

title: Trump Praises Controversial Hungarian Leader
summary: U.S. leader defends Viktor Orban during a rare White House visit by a prime minister whose policies on migrants and the press have been widely criticized. President Trump offered praise on Monday for Hungary's controversial prime minister during the European leader's first White House visit in more than 20 years, describing him as a highly respected figure who has done what he must to keep his country safe.

title: The Cost of China Tariffs
summary: Border taxes are an economic loss, as markets are saying.. President Trump often cites the stock market as proof of his economic-policy success, so let's hope he was watching the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Monday. The Dow fell 2.38%, and the Nasdaq and Russell 2000 fell even more, on the escalating tariff dispute between the U.S. and China.

title: Springtime for Antitrust Lawyers
summary: Justice Kavanaugh joins the liberals to open a new avenue for lawsuits.. Liberals who want to broaden antitrust law in the digital economy received a surprising assist Monday from the Supreme Court. Joined by his liberal colleagues, Justice Brett Kavanaugh gutted four decades of precedent and opened an antitrust Pandora's Box by green-lighting a consumer lawsuit against Apple for overcharging app developers.

title: Bernie and AOC Are a Credit Risk
summary: They would cap interest at 15%, while letting the Post Office write loans.. Congress's two loudest socialists are teaming up to take on credit-card companies-while applying their familiar analytical skills to the economics. Sen. Bernie Sanders and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez last week proposed capping interest rates on consumer loans at 15%.

title: 'Religious Freedom in Islam' Review: Politics and Pluralism
summary: In the Muslim world, secularly repressive regimes have often fed the very problem they seek to suppress: religious extremism.. After revoking the Edict of Nantes, and with it the civil and religious liberties that the law had afforded Protestants in his realm, Louis XIV boasted that France had become the most intolerant land in Europe. At the time, intolerance was seen as a political virtue-akin today to the notion of "zero tolerance." It was a moral universe that would be upended in the following century when the American and French revolutions gave rise to a new political philosophy based on tolerance, secularism, freedom of conscience and religious liberty.

title: Boomer Bequest Is Millennial Misery
summary: Saddled with student and public debt, today's young adults will long pay the price for our elders' folly.. Will 2020 be the political year of the millennial? It ought to be. Some 27% of next year's electorate will belong to that generation, born between 1981 and 1996-almost exactly matched with the 28% comprised of baby boomers (1946-64). The oldest of us-I was born in 1982-are eligible to run for the presidency. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard, 38, and Mayor Pete Buttigieg, 37, are doing so.

title: American Intelligence Needs Reform After Spygate
summary: The warrant against Carter Page violated a decades-old norm. And what was the CIA up to in Britain?. Attorney General William Barr got attention when he told Congress he'd examine the origins and predicate for the Federal Bureau of Investigation's counterintelligence probe of the Trump campaign. He surely set off alarms in certain precincts when he added: "I am not talking about the FBI necessarily, but intelligence agencies more broadly."

title: Crossing the Aisle to Streamline Regulation
summary: Lankford and Sinema aim at improvements in the process that have eluded presidents of both parties.. Bipartisanship isn't dead, even when it comes to streamlining regulation. Sens. James Lankford (R., Okla.) and Kyrsten Sinema (D., Ariz.) have introduced two bills with surgical fixes to the regulatory process-one to promote public engagement; the other, a review of existing regulations with an eye toward changing course if they aren't working. Presidents from both parties have pursued both objectives with uneven results, so a legislative fix would be salutary.

title: Vaccines Made the Iron Lung Obsolete
summary: Thanks to brilliant medical researchers, many schoolchildren have never even heard of polio.. Just off U.S. route 30 in western Nebraska, on Buffalo Bill Avenue, sits the Lincoln County Historical Museum. Inside is an unexpected exhibit that I think about as a cruel and unnecessary measles outbreak spreads in the U.S.

We have now arrived at stage two: an omnibus contempt bill.

title: Old Sears Fights With Foreign Suppliers on Merchandise Bought in Bankruptcy
summary: Vendors demand full payment as bankruptcy estate flirts with insolvency. A dispute between the bankrupt shell company left behind after Edward Lampert's purchase of Sears Holdings Corp.'s top stores and a number of foreign vendors is heating up.

title: What 'America First' Means to Pompeo
summary: The secretary of state elaborates on Trump's slogan, appealing to the Founders' vision.. The U.S. faces a series of intractable crises and standoffs around the world. Trade talks with China have reached an impasse; North Korea has returned to threats and missile launches; the chaos on America's southern border shows no sign of abating; relations with Germany reached new lows after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo canceled a meeting with Chancellor Angela Merkel so he could visit Iraq; Venezuela's Nicolás Maduro continues to defy U.S. pressure to stand down; and an apparent act of sabotage against ships in the Persian Gulf Monday ratcheted tensions another notch higher in the Middle East.

title: Measles Outbreaks, Up to 839 Cases, Show No Sign of Slowing
summary: This year is the worst for measles in U.S. in 25 years. The number of U.S. measles cases has reached 839 in 23 states, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Monday in a weekly update, as outbreaks in parts of the country showed no sign of slowing down.

title: In Latest Roundup Defeat for Bayer, Jury Awards Couple $2 Billion
summary: Jury verdict comes as Bayer faces shareholder revolt, exposure to some 13,400 claims tying its weedkiller to cancer. title: Supreme Court Allows Apple Apps Antitrust Case to Proceed

title: Crossing the Barr and Blatant Partisanship
summary: The way Congress acknowledges that the executive branch is a coequal branch is by following this simple rule: staff meets with staff, and principals meet with principals.. Regarding Kimberley Strassel's "For Fear of William Barr" (Potomac Watch, May 3): While Ms. Strassel makes some excellent points, she misses the critically important constitutional issue in House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler's "move to hold Mr. Barr in contempt unless the attorney general acquiesces to the unprecedented demand that he submit to cross-examination by committee staff attorneys."

title: Google's Censorship Needs Careful Response
summary: Asking government to look over Google's shoulder would likely be worse.. Regarding Ryan P. Williams's "Our Brush With Google Censorship" (op-ed, May 8): Google's suppression of Claremont Institute ads for speech that Google's own employees couldn't identify is terrifying. The problem is what to do about it. Asking government to look over Google's shoulder would likely be worse.

title: Multiemployer Pension Plans' Bad Incentives
summary: Neither employer nor union trustees had much of an incentive to worry about the ratio of assets to liabilities.. Jeffrey M. Lesser's May 6 letter accuses you of misrepresenting multiemployer pension plans as "union run" in your editorial "Big Labor's Big Shrink" (April 30). He points out that multiemployer plans actually are run by equal numbers of employer and union trustees and argues that they have provided decent pensions to millions of union employees for many years.

title: Persuade the Confused and Ignorant on Science Issues
summary: We shouldn't become scientific zealots by silencing, ridiculing or playing down the genuine concerns of people on the fringe.. Regarding Michael Segal's "The Complicated Truth about Vaccines" (op-ed, May 2): This type of argument is everything that's needed in our society today. Whether it's global warming, genetic engineering, biotech or the future of vaccines, the complex science of all of these issues needs to be debated in the spirit that scientific consensus doesn't justify dogma. We shouldn't become scientific zealots by silencing, ridiculing or playing down the genuine concerns of people on the fringe, because engagement with such arguments actually strengthens the science and leads to better solutions. If only everyone could follow Dr. Segal's example across the range of science policy issues we face.

Playing To Kill A Mockingbird protagonist Atticus Finch to Broadway was especially tricky because of his attempts to complicate the character's traditionally depicted narrative. Daniels had to expose Finch's moral flaws, rather than imitate the valiant figure Gregory Peck played in the 1962 movie version of Harper Lee's novel (published two years before it was adapted to film).

title: How Spike Lee and Idris Elba's Tailor is Modernizing the Suit
summary: British tailor Ozwald Boateng hosted a suit-heavy fashion show with an African edge at the Apollo Theater in Harlem. HARLEM'S APOLLO THEATER has staged raucous, foot-stomping concerts starring heavyweights like B.B. King, Aretha Franklin and James Brown, but on May 5, the 105-year-old theater hosted a different sort of performance: a 60-look fashion show by London-based designer Ozwald Boateng. "It's a powerful statement to connect Africa, Europe and America in a spot called Harlem," said Mr. Boateng, a Brit of Ghanian heritage best known for men's tailored suits. "From a diaspora point of view, it's a big message," he said of the opportunity to show at one of New York's living temples to black culture, noting that, coincidentally, 2019 is the 100th anniversary of the Harlem Renaissance.

title: The Sum of the Parts of STEM Toys Can Equal a Giant Mess
summary: A new generation of knickknacks meant to inspire a love of science and math can become a headache for parents; Legos aren't the only floor hazard. After baking a batch of cookies with his three grandchildren, Melvin Albright realized something was amiss.

title: Food's Funny-Looking Future: 'Ugly' Produce Delivery
summary: Should fruits and vegetables go to waste just because they're not pretty? These home-delivery subscription services find a market for the misshapen.. LOPSIDED RED PEPPERS. Bent potatoes. Scratched eggplants. To Liselle Pires, it's all delicious.

title: Rising Rents for Millennials Give Rise to a New Breed of Lender
summary: New lenders are entering what was once the realm of payday lending, pitching loans to young renters in increasingly unaffordable cities. Jennifer Burnes says the paychecks from her work as a model and designer in Hollywood arrive sporadically, posing a challenge to paying monthly rent. "You know the check's on the way, you just don't know when, exactly," the 22-year-old said.

title: Trade Fight Escalates as China Hits U.S. With Higher Tariffs
summary: Washington lays out nearly $300 billion of imports that would face fresh 25% levies. The U.S.-China trade dispute escalated sharply Monday, as Beijing retaliated against higher U.S. tariffs with plans to increase levies on $60 billion in U.S. imports and Washington laid out nearly $300 billion of new Chinese imports that would face 25% levies as early as this summer.

title: China Holds Fire After Trade Talks Fail to Find Deal
summary: Cautious about harming its economy, Beijing is waiting before retaliating against U.S. tariff increases. BEIJING-China held back from immediate retaliation for higher U.S. tariffs, unlike in past rounds, taking time to weigh its options amid uncertainty over how the Chinese economy would weather a full-bore trade conflict.
